review_title: Generally Positive, but Not A Great Place To Grow A Career
job_title: Lead Applications Analyst in Denver, CO
pros:
This is an organization focused on taking care of people no one else will.

It is possible for even mid-level employees to facilitate meaningful change.

There is a lot of flexibility in how members of my team are allowed to approach their work, and the work life balance is pretty great.
cons:
The pay is pretty far below comparitive positions at other Denver-area healthcare organizations (for my role).

There are no meaningful incentives for being a star employee. The result is that most of the star employees leave seeking greener pastures (and appropriate compensation), and the low-performers are the ones who stick around until retirement.

There is very little opportunity for advancement or meaningful salary increases. 

The organization frequently operates in the red. There is rarely any budget to pursue new ideas, and many of the years I've worked here have included furloughs and layoffs.

The senior leadership structure is convoluted, and getting high-level decisions made (or communicated) is almost always tedious.

Unless you have built a lot of clout over many years, Denver Health is not a very safe place to stick your neck out. Some individual teams embrace a "to fail is to learn" ethos, but most entities within the organization are quick to condemn people whose ideas don't pan out.

pros: - Love what the company stands for and willingness to help those in need. - Depending on department, staff is flexible and understanding. - Diversity and culture is fantastic.
cons: - Micromanagement is rampant in certain departments. - Way too many people in management positions. - Constant "required" meetings that take up valuable time. - Virtually everything is running behind or using old software.

pros: Denver Health is a safety net hospital, so if you care about working with at-risk populations, this is the hospital where you will get that the most

Their inability to follow through with promises, advocate for staff, show up to meetings, or interact positively with staff is horrifying. They will gaslight, punish, and retaliate against you at will. Staff drop like flies due to their horrible mismanagement, and they continue to lie to the higher ups as to why their department is bleeding. If you are considering becoming a SW or an RNCC at Denver Health, run in the other direction. It generally takes new staff members 1-2 weeks to realize they made a mistake coming here.

Fired for being accused of nonsensical hypocritical things after filing for Worker's Compensation (which I didn't get because it wasn't accessible and their inner staff for the 'Ouch' worker's comp dept. are horrible to work with if you have an accent). After getting hit in the head with a large piece of metal, I was expected to work to the same degree and often wasn't allowed sufficient bathroom breaks that I had to start buying adult diapers if I could not hold it. As an Asian woman working BOH, the rest of the staff typically has a ganging up on you mentality if you come from a different race and background. They often fabricate lies and when you try to tell people about the discrimination you face they label you as gossiping and spreading rumors. I was often told to go back to my country, asked why I have slanted eyes, and told to speak better when I have an accent. When you tell your HR, they are reluctant to listen to the minority group and tend to listen to the larger group of people that clique together. This is NOT a safe place to work.

review_title: IT Help Desk = micromanaged call center
job_title: IT Support Specialist I in Denver, CO
pros: The only actual "pro" is that I have a new standard for what constitutes terrible management. The hypocrisy, treatment of employees, and lack of outward managerial/supervisory skillsets drove dozens of good and hard working co-workers to the point of leaving (8 people from my department quit in the same MONTH I did)
cons: You are hired to do "IT help desk" work, but it takes about your first 2 calls to realize you are a secretary for the actual IT and Epic teams. You have access to do password resets in very few applications and if you ask for more access to complete even the most basic functions, you are now a "behaviorial issue" and any chance for advancement is gone. The actual IT and Epic personnel are in a separate location, so you will never meet any of them, but they can and do IM you to tell you how awful the help desk is. Overall this was one of the worst professional experiences of my life and would never recommend anyone with any sort of IT experience to work here.  The reviewers below had I correct when they state how poor management is, and considering those reviews come from many different departments, obviously it wasn't just me and is a systemic problem throughout the entire organization.

pros: -Benefits are about the only pro, but you wont last long enough to make them count.
cons:
-Salary, i've been getting paid significantly more after leaving.
-IT Management. They have a system of promoting poorly performing employees to higher paying jobs based on years in the seat. Most old timers have been on every IT team. The issue is that they place a burden on new employees that are actually skilled and talented. Then they put up a wall around themselves for protection, hence the high turnover rates. The best example of this is the CTO. He started as a desktop tech probably 20 years ago or more? Nows he's a CTO that couldnt tell you the difference between WindowsXP/7/OSX. Someone not having a clue about technology, i think is safe to say, wont make for a good CTO. 
-The secret to success here is to brown nose and quickly align yourself with management. It makes me sick that this is how a hospital can be ran, not for the benefit of their patients and the community, but in the best interests of themselves.
-The politics are deep and far reaching here. If you're good at your job, you wont like working here.

cons:
-I made a confidential complaint to HR about my boss, HR forwarded it directly to my boss. Not even exaggerating. They did nothing to address my complaint or rectify the situation, even after committing this illegal and unethical transgression.

-Toxic hospital environment. Call out sick or have a approved medical condition? Get ready to get chewed out the next day. Better to come in and get more people sick.

-I worked there for years, not one time was it staffed appropriately. Why would they bother when they can just pay less people? They have no incentive to staff properly.

-They make money hand over fist, but do nothing to pass this employees. They literally make hundreds of millions from the coverage homeless receive from Obamacare which they used to have to treat for free, somehow still too broke to give raises or cost of living increases.

-Every good employee leaves for greener pastures, leaving the bottom of the barrel.

-1% raise once a year. My rent went up over $200 a month during my time there, guess how much this helped?

review_title: DHMP/Managed Care - Beware of the Toxic Environment & Instability
pros: The benefits that are offered through DHHA are excellent.  The retirement contributions, EcoPass, and PTO are very good relative to other employers.
cons:
This ended up being one of the most toxic work experiences of my entire career, and it didn't have to be.  I happened to be hired in right before a major re-org, and it went all down hill from there.  

Attrition was a major in issue in just about every department.  For the past couple of years, there was a massive exodus of knowledge and talent.  It seems that a big reason for this is lack of advancement opportunities, and overwhelming top performers with lots of additional work with little or no reward.  It think there was something like 30-40% attrition in the health plan over the past couple of years at all levels and across the org.

Career opportunities were severely lacking during my tenure with the health plan.  Management had no problem piling on more work and giving you more responsibilities.  But when it came time for seeking advancement, there were always excuses for why it wasn't the right time for you.  It seemed to be easy to get in, but it was impossible to move up.  Management seems to be more focused on hiring from the outside than promoting from the inside.  As a result, I've seen a lot of people leave, and some will even come back years later when they are hired into better positions than they left.

Silos/backstabbing and poor operational planning was some of the worst I've ever experienced with an organization.  I think it's a result of teams being overwhelmed and understaffed due to lack of resources.  So when they don't get work done, there is a bunch of finger pointing and blaming of other groups for not contributing,  Sometimes the criticisms were valid, but much of the time it was excuse making for poor planning and even worse execution.

I made some really good connections with the company, but I also observed and experienced some of the worst backstabbing in all of my years of experience.  People incessantly talk about others behind their backs, usually nitpicking and criticizing their work ethic or attitudes regardless of whether there is any truth or data to back it up.  I know this probably happens a lot more than I'm typically aware, but it really contributed to a negative culture.  You really didn't know who you could trust, and you never knew if someone was talking about you behind your back for no apparent rhyme or reason.

The upside is that a lot of the "old timers" have left or are being pushed out.  Due to all the turnover, lots of new blood have entered the ranks, and I actually think this is the best possible outcome for the organization.  Much of the negativity and animosity and backstabbing have left or will leave with the continued attrition of those who've been there too long.   As long as senior management handles the onboarding of new staff well enough, they can help create and cultivate a more positive culture within the organization.

Bottom line for me is that it was really bad timing to join the organization when I did, and I eventually dealt with as much of the chaos as I could before jumping ship.  I was hired on by managers with bad reputations, and those reputations seemed to rub off and stick with their legacy staff members.  In the end, I realized I never had a chance with this org, and was set up for failure (unintentionally) from the very beginning.  

I really hope the best for DHMP.  Despite my bad experience, I learned a lot and met and worked with some really good people.   Management seems to have brought in some really good people in the last six months.  I hope that they treat them well enough to retain them so that the culture continues to improve and the knowledge and experience stays with the company so that groups aren't in a perpetual state of rebuilding.

review_title: Went from the best hospital to work for in Denver to not.
pros:
Amazing teamwork and camaraderie between the staff. I worked in the ICU's for over 10 years, one of the main reasons being my relationships with co-workers and our shared passions of everything medicine. 

Cost and quality of employee health care coverage.

Retirement benefits.
cons:
This is being written by a former employee of over a decade who loves Denver Health very much. I am not posting this not to dissuade future employees or to intentionally defame, but rather as somebody who sees Denver Health as family and is trying everything they can to put an end to the treatment my family is being subjected to. 

The atmosphere throughout the hospital deteriorated throughout the last few years of my employment. It seemed to begin with the acquisition of our new CEO. For example, under the previous CEO's leadership, Dr. Gabow, the LEAN system of DH was one of the best. Employees constantly took on personal projects to help save money. Rapid improvement events were always ongoing to eliminate waste and improve productivity. The staff were challenged and encouraged to take on projects of their own. DH was in the black for several years. Not too bad for the safety net hospital! Employee attitudes were mostly positive. DH was a sought after hospital to work for by those who had a passion for medicine and a passion to help others. Those who only wanted a paycheck by doing the least amount of work possible generally didn't last long. DH didn't buy a certificate showing off that they were one of the best. Didn't need to. It was common knowledge throughout the industry and it showed.  

Shortly after changing CEO's, LEAN projects quickly went from an every day occurrence to only a memory. The head of LEAN abruptly retired shortly after staff projects ceased. Lean still exists today as a class offered to the public for a fee to obtain LEAN certification, but it is no longer a functioning entity within the hospital. 

The atmosphere changed. We were given larger workloads and more paperwork. Our jobs were constantly threatened by our micromanaging leadership. Computers are slow with clunky charting software that required so much time patient care suffered. Management wasn't concerned about how we cared for our patients, we were being watched to see if we crossed our t's and dotted our i's. Patients were ignored. Patient safety was compromised. Why? Because we had to become a "Magnet" hospital. 

About halfway through my career at DH money became tight. Our previous CEO, instead of imposing job cuts chose to stop yearly raises until things got better. The staff mostly accepted this and things eventually improved. At least nobody was laid off. Then our new CEO took over, cut the biggest money saving program we had in LEAN, and just a little over a year into his position announced 300 job cuts. 

Some valuable employees were fired for nonsense reasons. Colorado is a right to work state and employers don't need a reason to terminate. However, if an employee loses their job under no fault of their own, they can file for unemployment benefits and their former employer gets taxed. If they are terminated for being at fault, no benefits. I'm not saying veteran employees were being terminated so DH could save some more money. What I do know is two friends were fired under silly circumstances. Both times Denver Health immediately appealed to stop their unemployment. Seems suspect to me.

On occasion, our new CEO would come to the A.V. room  so he could practice with his band that he formed under the Denver Health Foundation. There were two A.V. employees. He would take one to run his band equipment, doubling the workload of the other. The A.V. person who received the increased work load was not very happy on days when they were busy. It didn't matter to the CEO. I felt sorry for them. 

We were too scared to do anything out of this fear they created. I'm not joking, it got to the point that I would act happy around anybody considered administration, avoid eye contact, and say very little strictly out of fear that they would find a reason to turn on me and that would be it.

I'm not going to say how my career ended with DH. I am concerned about how my friends are being treated and something needs to be done. I still talk to many of my former co-workers on a daily basis and it hasn't gotten any better.

Google the new CEO. He has an interesting history involving his being investigated for illegal financial practices. It's public record.

review_title: Steer clear from the Finacial Services department
job_title: Data Applications Analyst in Denver, CO
pros: Benfits is the only thing
cons:
I worked in the Financial Services department as a data applications analyst for less than a year and it would have been shorter if I could have found something to save me from this organization. When I was offered an opportunity to interview I was going skip the interview because I didn’t get a good vibe from human resources that they were eager or excited like most human resource or recruiting departments typically are.  Reflecting back on this, I wish I would have skipped the interview.

The interview was with three people including manager and two other senior leadership members, including the CFO. In that interview, the position we spoke about was entirely different from the one that was outlined in the posting. At the time, the description of the job posting wasn’t necessary something I wanted to do and instead, in our discussions, the job outlined in the interview was something I wanted to do and was eager to be offered the position. At the time they let me know I was going to report to one of the Associate CFO’s. When I received a call that I got the position, I was super excited and of course like many other people I had questions. It wasn’t until 2 days prior to my start date that I received an answer back to those questions and that I was now going to report to someone else in the department, one of which was in the interview. I decided to go with it, but that should have been another red flag of how disorganized and lack of communication on Denver Health’s part.

The first week was very stressful learning all the new systems, colleagues, managers, directors, processes, policies, etc. When it came down to my day to day activities, it was the complete opposite from what we initially spoke about in the interview. It was also different from the posting. My job was for someone to refresh pivot tables and run simple SQL extracts which were something I mastered 10 years ago. When I brought this up to my manager she was very quick to belittle me and say I was wrong. Keep in mind this was two weeks in and she already raised her voice and talked down to me as if I was her child. I kept my cool and went back to my desk and started looking for a new job, even begged my previous employer if I could come back. I spent 8 months under my manager where I was constantly badgered, harassed, belittled, and treated like dirt. I was so upset that one day I went to her manager and he said he would look into it. Months went by and the behavior continued. While yes people may say, why didn’t you have a discussion with your manager? I did. Did you talk back? No, I voiced my concerns with how I was being treated, but that didn’t work. Come to find out after a few months, we hired another person in our department doing the same thing I do, but more senior level. It took three days for this individual to find out and it was actually refreshing to know it wasn’t just me. Later on, fellow colleagues reached out to me asking how I could work for her, she is the reason why the other 4 people left, etc., etc. It wasn’t much longer after that I just put in my two weeks’ notice without even having a job lined up because I just couldn’t take the harassment anymore. Some people would mention why didn’t I go to HR? My counter to that is that the work environment was already bad enough, bringing in HR would have made it worse, so it was just best to leave. I left because I felt abandoned by the system put in place and I wouldn’t wish upon anyone to work in these conditions. 
Conclusion
If you get an interview or a job offer from Denver Health in the Financial Services department, steer clear. Just a warning because myself and the colleague mentioned above weren’t the only two who had problems, it has been a revolving door per the words from colleagues in other departments. Every job I have had, I have loved who I worked for regardless if the job itself wasn’t the greatest. It is called respect and Denver Health doesn’t embody that trait.

review_title: Summary of Denver Health, and especially the IT department: A collection of incompetent employees and mismanagement.

There are a myriad of conflicts of interests in house which causes excessive work that can be otherwise be done without these forms of technology that Denver Health believes makes them one of the country's leaders in technology in the healthcare space. There is basically zero accountability from the employees and an exceptionally large collection of unintelligent employees in the IT department that just skate by and receive exceptional reviews and promotions based solely on tenure. There is an overdependence on a few employees that know what is going on and when these individuals take a day off projects and requests just stall. There have been countless times where on my day off my manager/supervisor kept blowing up my phone because there was an issue or request that he or the others on the team had no idea how to address.
